awd_titl_txt: University of Miami’s Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science: Research Vessel FG. Walton Smith SSSE
awd_abstract_narration:
A request is made to fund new instrumentation for the R/V Walton Smith, a 96,’ general purpose regional vessel operated and owned by the University of Miami’s Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (RSMAS) as part of the US Academic Fleet. These vessels are scheduled by the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS).  R/V Walton Smith conducts a substantial portion of her operations in the near shore waters of South Florida and the Gulf of Mexico, providing scientific information relevant to major environmental initiatives.  R/V Walton Smith completed 35 days in the pandemic-shortened 2020 season.  In 2021, the vessel is scheduled to sail 105 days with 33% (35 days) of the schedule for NSF.  With this proposal, Miami provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:      

Applanix POS MV OceanMaster

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
POS MV (Position & Orientation Systems for Marine Vessels) - an inertial navigation system for marine vessels that blends global navigation satellite data to compute and provide highly accurate and complete sets of parameters for latitude, longitude (position), heading, attitude, pitch, roll, heave and velocity. The system provides the necessary requirements for accurate marine motion sensing, hydrographic surveying and remote sensing equipment used in oceanographic and atmospheric research aboard vessels.  This data is critical for research on board our Research Vessel F.G. Walton Smith.  The POS MV OceanMaster provides sub-meter accuracy for position/heave and 0.02 degree accuracy for heading/pitch and roll.  This data is vital for collecting Acoustic Dopperl Current Profiler (ADCP) data.

A significant number of research cruises conducted aboard R/V F.G. Walton Smith occur in the waters near South Florida where several key ocean currents occur.  One such current is the Gulf Stream Current; it is a main conveyor of heat from south to north in the Atlantic.  The main oceanographic instrument to measure these currents is the Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP).  RVWS has two hull mounted ADCP systems on board and one removable pole mounted unit that can measure the ocean currents in as shallow as a few meters below the hull down to several hundred meters into the water column. The ADCPs measure the velocity of the water relative to the transducer so navigational data (position and heading) is critical for calculating the quantity and velocity of the water over the ocean bottom.  To calculate accurate ocean currents a heading value must be known to 0.1 degrees.  Mechanical or optical gyro compasses are reliable but they do not provide the degree of accuracy needed to collect valid, accurate ADCP data.  The POS MV instrument provides GPS together with inertial and gyro sensors with accuracies that are well within the specified requirements.

This instrument will better serve all oncoming scientists for the current calendar year, as well as future expeditions in years to come. The instrument requested is expected to support other NSF funded grants which have previously gained intellectual merit. The proposed item is an upgrade to existing equipment and the ship’s data collection system.

Several programs funded by NSF and supportive agencies will benefit from the proposed instrument for the ship schedules such as global weather modeling and ocean circulation.  These, among other current global issues, focus on the most impending oceanographic concerns today. Oceanographic research vessels provide a valuable service in the collection of scientific information which increases our understanding of the sea.  R/V F.G. Walton Smith is an extremely capable vessel for its size.  The University of Miami is continually improving the services that are offered to the scientific community aboard this unique vessel.

R/V F.G. Walton Smith provides many opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to participate in scientific cruises.  When in port (pre-pandemic), the ship is also opened for tours to local schools (K-12) and to the public during various events at the University of Miami’s Rosenstiel School of Marine, Atmospheric and Earth Science campus.  The requested item enables the ship to improve the quality of data that it provides.  Through the continual upgrading and modernization of equipment and instrumentation postdoctoral, graduate, undergraduate, high school, and technical program students, as well as, teachers and interns will benefit from the acquisition of new equipment. Those participating in the sponsored research programs supported by these acquisitions will have in-depth exposure to state-of-the-art oceanographic and atmospheric sciences.


Last Modified: 07/21/2022
Modified by: Don Cucchiara

POS MV (Position & Orientation Systems for Marine Vessels) - an  inertial navigation system for marine vessels that blends global  navigation satellite data to compute and provide highly accurate and  complete sets of parameters for latitude, longitude (position), heading,  attitude, pitch, roll, heave and velocity. The system provides the  necessary requirements for accurate marine motion sensing, hydrographic  surveying and remote sensing equipment used in oceanographic and  atmospheric research aboard vessels.  This data is critical for research  on board our Research Vessel F.G. Walton Smith.  The POS MV OceanMaster  provides sub-meter accuracy for position/heave and 0.02 degree accuracy  for heading/pitch and roll.  This data is vital for collecting Acoustic  Dopperl Current Profiler (ADCP) data.

A significant number of  research cruises conducted aboard R/V F.G. Walton Smith occur in the  waters near South Florida where several key ocean currents occur.  One  such current is the Gulf Stream Current; it is a main conveyor of heat  from south to north in the Atlantic.  The main oceanographic instrument  to measure these currents is the Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler  (ADCP).  RVWS has two hull mounted ADCP systems on board and one  removable pole mounted unit that can measure the ocean currents in as  shallow as a few meters below the hull down to several hundred meters  into the water column. The ADCPs measure the velocity of the water  relative to the transducer so navigational data (position and heading)  is critical for calculating the quantity and velocity of the water over  the ocean bottom.  To calculate accurate ocean currents a heading value  must be known to 0.1 degrees.  Mechanical or optical gyro compasses are  reliable but they do not provide the degree of accuracy needed to  collect valid, accurate ADCP data.  The POS MV instrument provides GPS together with inertial and gyro sensors with  accuracies that are well within the specified requirements.

This  instrument will better serve all oncoming scientists for the current  calendar year, as well as future expeditions in years to come. The instrument requested is expected to support other NSF funded  grants which have previously gained intellectual merit. The proposed  item is an upgrade to existing equipment and the ship’s data collection  system.

Several programs funded by NSF and supportive agencies  will benefit from the proposed instrument for the ship schedules such as  global weather modeling and ocean circulation.  These, among other  current global issues, focus on the most impending oceanographic  concerns today. Oceanographic research vessels provide a valuable  service in the collection of scientific information which increases our  understanding of the sea.  R/V F.G. Walton Smith is an extremely capable  vessel for its size.  The University of Miami is continually improving  the services that are offered to the scientific community aboard this  unique vessel.

R/V F.G. Walton Smith provides many opportunities for graduate and  undergraduate students to participate in scientific cruises.  When in  port (pre-pandemic), the ship is also opened for tours to local schools  (K-12) and to the public during various events at the University of  Miami’s Rosenstiel School of Marine, Atmospheric and Earth Science  campus.  The requested item enables the ship to improve the quality of  data that it provides.  Through the continual upgrading and modernization of equipment and instrumentation postdoctoral, graduate, undergraduate, high school, and technical program students, as well as, teachers and interns will benefit from the acquisition of new equipment. Those participating in the sponsored research programs supported by these acquisitions will have in-depth exposure to state-of-the-art oceanographic and atmospheric sciences.
